sen.j: 清原 深養父（きよはら の ふかやぶ、生没年不詳）は、平安時代中期の歌人。
sen.e: KIYOHARA no Fukayabu (dates unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.
KIYOHARA no Fukayabu (dates unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.
KIYOHARA no Fukayabu (year of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.
sen.cmt: スペース調整用語統一

sen.e: His father was Buzen no suke (Assistant Governor of Buzen Province), Fusanori KIYOHARA.
His father was Buzen no suke (Assistant Governor of Buzen Province), Fusanori KIYOHARA.
His father was Buzen no suke (Assistant Governor of Buzen Province), Fusanori KIYOHARA.

sen.j: 孫（子とする説もある）に清原元輔、曾孫（孫とする説もある）に清少納言がいる。
sen.e: KIYOHARA no Motosuke was his grandson (there is another theory that regards him as a son), and Sei Shonagon was his great-granddaughter (another theory considers her to have been his granddaughter).
KIYOHARA no Motosuke was his grandson (there is another theory that regards him as a son), and Sei Shonagon was his great-granddaughter (another theory considers her to have been his granddaughter).
KIYOHARA no Motosuke was his grandson (there is another theory that regards him as a son), and Sei Shonagon was his great-granddaughter (another theory considers her to have been his granddaughter).

sen.j: 中古三十六歌仙の一人。
sen.e: He is one of the Medieval Thirty-Six Immortal Poets.
He is one of the Medieval Thirty-Six Immortal Poets.
He is regarded as one of the medieval 36 Immortal Poets.

sen.j: 官職には恵まれず、908年（延喜8年）の内匠允、923年（延長 (日本)元年）の内蔵大允等を歴任、最終的には930年（延長8年）の従五位下内蔵大允におわった。
sen.e: He was unfortunate in promotions, and he ended his career as Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Takumi no Daijo in 930 after filling the posts of Takumi no Jo (Secretary of the Bureau of Skilled Artisans) in 908 and Takumi no Daijo (Senior Secretary of the Bureau of Skilled Artisans) in 923.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He was unfortunate in promotions, and he ended his career as Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Takumi no Daijo in 930 after filling the posts of Takumi no Jo (Secretary of the Bureau of Skilled Artisans) in 908 and Takumi no Daijo (Senior Secretary of the Bureau of Skilled Artisans) in 923.

He was unfortunate in promotions, and he ended his career as Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Takumi no Daijo in 930 after filling the posts of Takumi no Jo (Secretary of the Bureau of Skilled Artisans) in 908 and Takumi no Daijo (Senior Secretary of the Bureau of Skilled Artisans) in 923.

sen.j: が、「古今和歌集」に17首の歌が入集するなど、歌人としての評価は高かった。
sen.e: However, he had a good reputation as a poet: 17 poems of his were selected for the 'Kokin wakashu' (Collection of Ancient and Modern Poems).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, he had a good reputation as a poet: 17 poems of his were selected for the 'Kokin wakashu' (Collection of Ancient and Modern Poems).
However, he had a good reputation as a poet: 17 poems of his were selected for the 'Kokin wakashu' (Collection of Ancient and Modern Poems).

sen.j: 琴にも秀で、藤原兼輔・紀貫之・凡河内躬恒などと交流があった。
sen.e: He also excelled at playing the koto (Japanese zither), and was friends with FUJIWARA no Kanesuke, KI no Tsurayuki and OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune.
He also excelled at playing the koto (Japanese zither), and was friends with FUJIWARA no Kanesuke, KI no Tsurayuki and OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune.
He also excelled at playing the koto (Japanese zither), and was friends with FUJIWARA no Kanesuke, KI no Tsurayuki and OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune.

sen.j: 晩年は洛北岩倉に補陀落寺を建立し、隠棲したという。
sen.e: It is said that in his later years, he built Fudaraku-ji temple at Iwakura in the northern part of Kyoto and lived in seclusion.
It is said that in his later years, he built Fudaraku-ji temple at Iwakura in the northern part of Kyoto and lived in seclusion.
It is said that in his later years, he built Fudaraku-ji Temple at Iwakura in the northern part of Kyoto and lived in seclusion.

sen.j: 家集に「深養父集」がある。
sen.e: He left behind a personal collection 'Fukayabu Shu'.
He left behind a personal collection 'Fukayabu Shu.'
He left behind a personal collection 'Fukayabu Shu.'
"Ogura Hyakunin Isshu" ("The Ogura's Sequence of One Hundred Poems by One Hundred Poets")
"Ogura Hyakunin Isshu" ("The Ogura's Sequence of One Hundred Poems by One Hundred Poets")
Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (the Ogura Anthology of One Hundred Tanka-poems by One Hundred Poets)

sen.j: 36番 夏の夜は まだ宵ながら 明けぬるを 雲のいづくに 月宿るらむ（「古今和歌集」夏166）
sen.e: 36. The short summer night is already over though I thought it was evening still--where in the clouds, I wonder, will the moon stay. ('Kokin wakashu' Summer, 166)
36. The short summer night is already over though I thought it was evening still--where in the clouds, I wonder, will the moon stay. ('Kokin wakashu' Summer, 166)
